div.head: Thomas Lupton to the Reader.
div.l: JF such are worthy of reproche that neuer cease to toyle,
For priuate gayne, their country men therby to hurt or spoyle,
Then they deserue great prayse and fame, whose study watch & payn
Do profet them they neuer knew, wyth dayly welth & gayne,
And if the greater common good, the greater prayse doth craue,
Then they that publeck welth procures, deserues the more to haue.
For though wyth many worldly welth, is chiefly now preferd,
Yet syck and lame and yrcksome soore do health much more regard.
For who, though he haue Cresus welth in sicknes can be glad,
Wher health is not, though welth be there, what Ioy can ther be had.
Yet doth the poore and healthfull wretch oftymes reioyse we see,
But if that sicknes dwell with welth, then myrth from thens doth slee.
If this be trew, then Iones deserues both double prayse and fame,
That tooke such payns for comom helth, this Ayde of Baths to frame.
